perturbation.original_text: Seller hereby covenants and agrees, that from time to time forthwith upon the reasonable written request of Backhaul or Buyer, that Seller will, at Backhaul's cost and expense, do, execute, acknowledge and deliver or cause to be done, executed, acknowledged and delivered, each and all of such further acts, deeds, assignments, transfers, conveyances and assurances as may reasonably be required by Backhaul or Buyer in order to transfer, assign, convey and deliver unto and vest in Backhaul title to all right, title and interest of Seller in, to and under the Assigned Intellectual Property.
perturbation.changed_text: Seller hereby covenants and agrees, that from time to time within 180 days of the written request of Backhaul or Buyer, that Seller will, at Backhaul's cost and expense, do, execute, acknowledge and deliver or cause to be done, executed, acknowledged and delivered, each and all of such further acts, deeds, assignments, transfers, conveyances and assurances as may reasonably be required by Backhaul or Buyer in order to transfer, assign, convey and deliver unto and vest in Backhaul title to all right, title and interest of Seller in, to and under the Assigned Intellectual Property.
perturbation.explanation: The modification introduces a fixed timeframe of 'within 180 days' for the Seller to comply with requests from Backhaul or Buyer, replacing the original 'forthwith upon the reasonable written request.' This could be deemed unreasonable and contradict the implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in contract law, potentially hindering the timely transfer of intellectual property rights which Georgia Law requires to be addressed promptly. It could be argued that 180 days is an unreasonable delay for executing simple acts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Georgia's Uniform Commercial Code and common law principles regarding good faith and fair dealing in contracts. O.C.G.A. ยง 11-1-203 imposes an obligation of good faith in the performance or enforcement of every contract or duty within this title.

perturbation.original_text: This Intellectual Property Agreement shall be construed and interpreted according to the laws of the State of Georgia, applicable contracts to be wholly performed within the State of Georgia.
perturbation.changed_text: This Intellectual Property Agreement shall be construed and interpreted according to the laws of the State of Delaware, without regard to its conflict of laws principles.
perturbation.explanation: The contract originally specifies that Georgia law governs its interpretation. Changing this to Delaware law introduces a potential conflict, especially if Delaware law differs significantly from Georgia law on matters related to intellectual property assignment or contract interpretation. Since the Seller is a Delaware corporation, it could create ambiguity, and Georgia law emphasizes the importance of upholding contracts according to their clear terms and the intentions of the parties at the time of formation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Georgia contract law principles regarding choice of law and the enforcement of contracts according to their terms, particularly where the contract specifies Georgia law. Conflicting with O.C.G.A. ยง 13-2-1, which emphasizes the binding nature of contracts and the importance of upholding their terms.

perturbation.original_text: Delivery of an executed counterpart of a signature page to this Intellectual Property Agreement by facsimile shall be effective as delivery of a manually executed counterpart of this Intellectual Property Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Delivery of an executed counterpart of a signature page to this Intellectual Property Agreement by facsimile shall not be effective as delivery of a manually executed counterpart of this Intellectual Property Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause allows for facsimile signatures to be considered legally binding, equivalent to a manual signature. By negating this clause, the modified text introduces ambiguity and potential non-compliance with Georgia's Electronic Transactions Act (O.C.G.A. ยง 10-12-1 et seq.), which generally recognizes the validity of electronic signatures, including those transmitted via facsimile, unless otherwise specified by law. Eliminating the acceptance of facsimile signatures could impede the contract's enforceability if a party relies on a faxed signature.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Georgia Electronic Transactions Act (O.C.G.A. ยง 10-12-1 et seq.), which provides legal validity to electronic signatures and records, including those transmitted by facsimile, unless specifically excluded by law.
